description: From Middle English acounte, from Anglo-Norman acunte (“account”), from Old French aconte, from aconter (“to reckon”), from Latin computō (“to sum up”).

entries.meaning: (accounting) A registry of pecuniary transactions; a written or printed statement of business dealings or debts and credits, and also of other things subjected to a reckoning or review. [from c. 1300]
(banking) A bank account.
examples: The Pueblo bank has advised that the operator opened an account at that bank with currency, and a few days later withdrew the amount.

entries.meaning: A statement in general of reasons, causes, grounds, etc., explanatory of some event; a reason of an action to be done.
A reason, grounds, consideration, motive; a person's sake.
examples: Don't trouble yourself on my account.

entries.meaning: A record of events; a relation or narrative. [from c. 1610]
examples: Synonyms: narrative, narration, relation, recital, report, description, explanation

entries.meaning: An estimate or estimation; valuation; judgment.
Importance; worth; value; esteem; judgement.
Authorization as a specific registered user in accessing a system.
examples: I've opened an account with Wikipedia so that I can contribute and partake in the project.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A reckoning; computation; calculation; enumeration; a record of some reckoning.
examples: It seems that this severity weakened his frame, for three years syne come Martinmas he was taken ill with a fever of the bowels, and after a week's sickness he went to his account, where I trust he is accepted.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Profit; advantage.
examples: The young man soon turned his woodworking skills to some account.

description: From Old French acounter, accomptere et al., from a- + conter (“to count”)). Compare count.

verbs.description: account (third-person singular simple present accounts, present participle accounting, simple past and past participle accounted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To present an account of; to answer for, to justify. [14th–17th c.]
(intransitive, now rare) To give an account of financial transactions, money received etc. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To estimate, consider (something to be as described). [from 14th c.]
(intransitive) To consider that. [from 14th c.]
(intransitive) To give a satisfactory evaluation for financial transactions, money received etc. [from 15th c.]
examples: An officer must account with or to the treasurer for money received.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give a satisfactory evaluation for (one's actions, behaviour etc.); to answer for. [from 16th c.]
examples: We must account for the use of our opportunities.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give a satisfactory reason for; to explain. [from 16th c.]
(intransitive) To establish the location for someone. [from 19th c.]
examples: After the crash, not all passengers were accounted for.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cause the death, capture, or destruction of someone or something (+ for). [from 19th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To calculate, work out (especially with periods of time). [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) To count (up), enumerate. [14th–17th c.]
(obsolete) To recount, relate (a narrative etc.). [14th–16th c.]
